Dialogue.Student: Hi, I’m Liam Johnson. It's nice to meet you!
Dialogue.Counselor: Hello, Liam! It’s great to meet you too. What brings you in today?
Dialogue.Student: I’m really excited about this semester. I’m studying Political Science and looking forward to getting involved in advocacy work.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds fantastic! Advocacy work can be very rewarding. Do you have any specific goals for this semester?
Dialogue.Student: Well, I want to secure an internship, but I’m feeling anxious about the competition and managing my grades. Plus, my sister Priya is struggling in high school, and I want to support her.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s commendable that you want to help your sister while also pursuing your goals. How do you feel about balancing these responsibilities?

Dialogue.Student: Hi again. I’m feeling really overwhelmed right now.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hello, Liam! I’m glad to see you back. What’s been making you feel overwhelmed?
Dialogue.Student: It’s just a lot. Between classes, trying to help Priya, and my responsibilities in student government, I feel exhausted.
Dialogue.Counselor: That does sound like a heavy load to carry. Have you had any time to take care of yourself amidst all these commitments?
Dialogue.Student: Not really. I haven’t been able to play soccer or hang out with friends much, and I miss that.
Dialogue.Counselor: Self-care is really important, especially when you’re balancing so much. What if you set aside just a small amount of time each week to engage in those activities?

Dialogue.Student: Hey, I just came back from a group meeting and I felt really inadequate.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi, Liam. I’m sorry to hear that. What made you feel inadequate during the meeting?
Dialogue.Student: I struggled to contribute meaningfully, and my peers ended up picking up the slack. I just felt so lost.
Dialogue.Counselor: It's understandable to feel that way, especially under pressure. Did you talk with anyone in your group about how you were feeling?
Dialogue.Student: I talked to Josh, but I’m still feeling disheartened. I keep doubting my abilities both academically and as a brother.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s a tough position to be in. You’re trying to support yourself and your sister, and it’s okay to feel overwhelmed. What would you consider as a practical step to regain your confidence?

Dialogue.Student: Hi! I went to see a counselor on campus, and it felt good to talk about everything I’ve been experiencing.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s great to hear, Liam! How did it feel to express your feelings?
Dialogue.Student: It was relieving. They suggested I try setting some boundaries and prioritize self-care, but I’m unsure if I can really do that.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s completely normal to feel unsure about making changes. What’s one specific boundary you could start with this week?
Dialogue.Student: Maybe I could reserve some time for soccer practice a couple of days a week—that would help me mentally.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds like a positive step! Remember, taking care of yourself will ultimately help you support others better. Keep me posted on how it goes!
Dialogue.Student: Thank you for your support! I really appreciate it.
